articles.headline: Full Picture of Airlines’ Punctuality Is Elusive
articles.snippet: Statistics exclude segments of the industry that have grown in recent years, and a proposed rule that would require more accuracy remains delayed.
articles.abstract: Statistics exclude segments of the industry that have grown in recent years, and a proposed rule that would require more accuracy remains delayed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Travelers on Monday experienced a new round of cancellations and delays as another winter storm grounded planes yet again. But many of those flights won’t be counted as late or canceled in the government’s on-time statistics.

articles.headline: As Recovery Looks Weak, Stocks Take a Deep Dive
articles.snippet: Poor numbers on factory orders and car sales left investors wondering if their view of the economy was too rosy, and the three major indexes each fell more than 2 percent.
articles.abstract: Poor numbers on factory orders and car sales left investors wondering if their view of the economy was too rosy, and the three major indexes each fell more than 2 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Signs of weakness in the American economy pushed Wall Street to its worst day in an already bad year.

articles.headline: Fast Internet Is Chattanooga’s New Locomotive
articles.snippet: Internet service that is inexpensive and lightning quick has allowed the city to attract high-tech businesses, talent and capital.
articles.abstract: Internet service that is inexpensive and lightning quick has allowed the city to attract high-tech businesses, talent and capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — For thousands of years, Native Americans used the river banks here to cross a gap in the Appalachian Mountains, and trains sped through during the Civil War to connect the eastern and western parts of the Confederacy. In the 21st century, it is the Internet that passes through Chattanooga, and at lightning speed.

articles.headline: At Four Seasons, Picasso Tapestry Hangs on the Edge of Eviction
articles.snippet: On the surface, the dispute about the planned removal of “Le Tricorne” at the Four Seasons in New York is about grout and tiles, but it is also a collision of values and taste.
articles.abstract: On the surface, the dispute about the planned removal of “Le Tricorne” at the Four Seasons in New York is about grout and tiles, but it is also a collision of values and taste.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, it has hung in the hallway of the Four Seasons Restaurant on Park Avenue, an immense work by one of the greatest artists of the 20th century. But Picasso’s curtain is coming down — and that might just destroy it.

articles.headline: Detroit Turns Bankruptcy Into Challenge of Banks
articles.snippet: Financial institutions that helped raise money for Detroit’s pension system are dismayed now to see themselves portrayed as shady characters in the city’s lawsuit.
articles.abstract: Financial institutions that helped raise money for Detroit’s pension system are dismayed now to see themselves portrayed as shady characters in the city’s lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Detroit’s bankruptcy is rapidly shaping up as a battle of Wall Street vs. Main Street, at least as far as the city’s creditors are concerned.

articles.headline: Karzai Arranged Secret Contacts With the Taliban
articles.snippet: President Hamid Karzai’s contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace deal could explain why he has held up a security deal, straining his relationship with the United States.
articles.abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace deal could explain why he has held up a security deal, straining his relationship with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has been engaged in secret contacts with the Taliban about reaching a peace agreement without the involvement of his American and Western allies, further corroding already strained relations with the United States.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Too Many Sorry Excuses for Apology
articles.snippet: The art of the apology has become a choreographed dance: Say you’re sorry, act vulnerable, tell everyone you’re “taking responsibility” and end with, “I hope to put this behind me.”
articles.abstract: The art of the apology has become a choreographed dance: Say you’re sorry, act vulnerable, tell everyone you’re “taking responsibility” and end with, “I hope to put this behind me.”
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems that just about every day a chief executive, politician or other prominent figure is apologizing for something.

articles.headline: With New App, Facebook Aims to Make Its Users’ Feeds Newsier
articles.snippet: Editors will supplement Facebook’s computers in recommending articles and blog posts on a dozen topics.
articles.abstract: Editors will supplement Facebook’s computers in recommending articles and blog posts on a dozen topics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg dreams of a day when Facebook’s computers would know you and your habits so well that it would deliver exactly the information you want to see — what he calls “the best personalized newspaper in the world.”
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: In Rapid Turnaround, Toyota Is on Track to Post Record Earnings
articles.snippet: After enduring huge recalls, a tsunami in Japan and a steep drop in sales because of slowing demand, Toyota said it was on pace to earn its biggest-ever annual profit in its fiscal year that ends in March.
articles.abstract: After enduring huge recalls, a tsunami in Japan and a steep drop in sales because of slowing demand, Toyota said it was on pace to earn its biggest-ever annual profit in its fiscal year that ends in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — While the American automakers have made drastic comebacks since the recession, no car company has had a bigger revival than Toyota.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Bill Vlasic
